DataElement.preferredName: Diffuse Large B-Cell Lymphoma Cell-of-Origin Assay Outcome Type
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Information related to the outcome of the kind of cell associated with the origin of diffuse large b-cell lymphoma.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Diffuse Large B-Cell Lymphoma Cell-of-Origin Assay Outcome
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A non-Hodgkin lymphoma characterized by a diffuse proliferation of predominantly large neoplastic B lymphocytes.  It is the most frequently seen type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma, representing 30%-40% of the cases.  Morphologic variants include centroblastic lymphoma, immunoblastic lymphoma, and anaplastic lymphoma.  Subtypes/entities include T-cell/histiocyte rich large B-cell lymphoma, primary diffuse large B-cell lymphoma of the central nervous system, plasmablastic lymphoma, primary cutaneous diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, leg type, and ALK-positive large B-cell lymphoma._An assay that utilizes gene expression profiling of RNA extracted from formalin-fixed, paraffin-embedded tissue biopsies, in order to determine the cell of origin of the tumor._The result of an action.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: This non-Hodgkin's lymphoma is characterized by a diffuse proliferation of predominantly large neoplastic B lymphocytes.  It is the most frequently seen type of non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, representing 30%-40% of the cases.  Morphologic variants include centroblastic lymphoma, immunoblastic lymphoma, T-cell/histiocyte rich lymphoma, anaplastic lymphoma, plasmablastic lymphoma, and diffuse large B-cell lymphoma with expression of full-length ALK. (WHO, 2001) -- 2003

Concepts.definition: A non-Hodgkin lymphoma characterized by a diffuse proliferation of predominantly large neoplastic B lymphocytes.  It is the most frequently seen type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma, representing 30%-40% of the cases.  Morphologic variants include centroblastic lymphoma, immunoblastic lymphoma, and anaplastic lymphoma.  Subtypes/entities include T-cell/histiocyte rich large B-cell lymphoma, primary diffuse large B-cell lymphoma of the central nervous system, plasmablastic lymphoma, primary cutaneous diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, leg type, and ALK-positive large B-cell lymphoma.

Property.preferredDefinition: An assay that utilizes gene expression profiling of RNA extracted from formalin-fixed, paraffin-embedded tissue biopsies, in order to determine the cell of origin of the tumor.:The result of an action.

Concepts.definition: An assay that utilizes gene expression profiling of RNA extracted from formalin-fixed, paraffin-embedded tissue biopsies, in order to determine the cell of origin of the tumor.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

ValueDomain.preferredName: Diffuse Large B-Cell lymphoma Cell Of Origin Type
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: The kind of cell associated with the origin of diffuse large b-cell lymphoma.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Activated B-Cell-Like Diffuse Large B-Cell Lymphoma

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A biologic subset of diffuse large B-cell lymphomas with a unique molecular signature or expression profile.  It represents approximately 30% of diffuse large B-cell lymphomas, and is characterized by the expression of CD44, PKCbeta1, Cyclin D2, BCL-2, and IRF4/MUM1 genes.  Morphologically, these lymphomas are either centroblastic or immunoblastic (ratio 2:1).  Patients with this type of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma are reported to have a less favorable outcome compared to those with a germinal center B-cell expression profile, with a 5-year survival rate of 35% and a median survival of 2 years.

Concepts.longName: Diffuse Large B-Cell Lymphoma Activated B-Cell Type
Concepts.definition: A biologic subset of diffuse large B-cell lymphomas with a unique molecular signature or expression profile.  It represents approximately 30% of diffuse large B-cell lymphomas, and is characterized by the expression of CD44, PKCbeta1, Cyclin D2, BCL-2, and IRF4/MUM1 genes.  Morphologically, these lymphomas are either centroblastic or immunoblastic (ratio 2:1).  Patients with this type of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma are reported to have a less favorable outcome compared to those with a germinal center B-cell expression profile, with a 5-year survival rate of 35% and a median survival of 2 years.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Germinal Center B-Cell-Like Diffuse Large B-Cell Lymphoma

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A biologic subset of diffuse large B-cell lymphomas with a unique molecular signature or expression profile.  It represents approximately 50% of diffuse large B-cell lymphomas, and is characterized by the expression of CD10, BCL-6, A-myb, and LMO2 genes, BCL-2 translocation, and c-REL amplification.  Morphologically, the vast majority of these lymphomas are centroblastic and a small minority are immunoblastic (ratio20:1).  Patients with this type of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma have a more favorable outcome, with a 5-year survival rate of 60% and a median survival of 10 years.

Concepts.longName: Diffuse Large B-Cell Lymphoma Germinal Center B-Cell Type
Concepts.definition: A biologic subset of diffuse large B-cell lymphomas with a unique molecular signature or expression profile.  It represents approximately 50% of diffuse large B-cell lymphomas, and is characterized by the expression of CD10, BCL-6, A-myb, and LMO2 genes, BCL-2 translocation, and c-REL amplification.  Morphologically, the vast majority of these lymphomas are centroblastic and a small minority are immunoblastic (ratio20:1).  Patients with this type of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma have a more favorable outcome, with a 5-year survival rate of 60% and a median survival of 10 years.
